Fig. 1 Effect of AgCl amount on the catalytic performance of AgClx-Ag20 /BaCO3 (A) and AgClx-Ag20 Cu/BaCO3 (B) for the epoxidation of propylene at 200 °C and GHSV of 2000 h−1. Fig. 2 Effect of reaction temperature on the epoxidation of propylene over Cl-Ag20 Cu/BaCO3 catalyst at GHSV of 2000 h−1. Fig. 3 The performance of Cl-Ag20 Cu/BaCO3 catalyst as a function of time on stream (A), catalytic activities of deactivated and regenerated Cl-Ag20 Cu/BaCO3 catalysts at 200 °C and GHSV of 2000 h−1 (B). Fig. 4 HAADF-STEM and EDS Mapping of Ag20 Cu/BaCO3 (A) and Cl-Ag20 Cu/BaCO3 catalysts (B). Fig. 5 H2-TPR profiles of Ag/BaCO3 , Cl-Ag/BaCO3 and Cu/BaCO3 (A); Cl-Ag20 Cux /BaCO3 with Ag/Cu (mol) of 20/1, 20/2 and 20/4 (B); and 2400 ppm Cl-Ag20 Cu/BaCO3 catalyst pretreated with oxygen at 200 °C/0.5 h or oxygen and then propylene at 200 °C/1h (C); Cl-Ag20 Cu/BaCO3 deposited with different AgCl loadings (D). Fig. 6 a and b are optimized OMMPʹ structure and the corresponding transition state structure for its o-o cleavage on Ag (111) surface, respectively; c and d indicate the transition state structures of AHS’ and OMMPʹ formation reactions; e, reaction profile of primary chemistry following atomic and molecular oxygen mechanism on two Cu substituted Ag (111) surface. Graphical abstract As molecular oxygen is the cheapest oxidant, the epoxidation of propylene by molecular oxygen is a topic of great interest and also the most challenge topic in the heterogeneous catalysis. However, the epoxidation of propylene by only molecular oxygen has yet to be optimised to a significant extent. Here we show, AgCl-modified Ag20Cu/BaCO3 bimetallic catalysts, prepared by in situ reduction co-deposition methods, were demonstrated to exhibit excellent catalytic activity for the epoxidation of propylene. First-principles density functional theory calculations were carried out to explore the inherent reaction mechanism and promotion effect of Cu and Cl addition. The addition of AgCl to Ag20Cu/BaCO3 bimetallic catalyst inhibited total oxidation of propylene, but enhanced both the rate of PO formation and PO selectivity. The highest PO selectivity of ∼100 % was achieved over 2400 ppm AgCl-Ag20Cu-/BaCO3 bimetallic catalyst at 80 °C. Keywords Epoxidation of propylene AgCl-modified Selectivity Reaction mechanism Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Propylene oxide (PO) is a key industrial feedstock used in the production of polyurethanes, unsaturated resins, surfactants, and various other chemicals. Traditionally, PO is predominantly produced via the chlorohydrin, Halcon, and HPPO processes. A major limitation of the chlorohydrin process is its reliance on large quantities of chlorine, a toxic substance that can also cause equipment corrosion. In the Halcon process, PO is produced together with the equimolar amount of co-product whose value depends on its demand in the market [1]. Molecular oxygen, being the most cost-effective oxidant, has garnered significant interest as an alternative for the epoxidation of propylene. However, the development of efficient technologies for propylene epoxidation using molecular oxygen remains underdeveloped. This is largely due to the weak nature of the allylic C–H bond, which is prone to oxidation, leading to the formation of CO2 and H2O rather than the desired epoxide product. Numerous studies have been dedicated to the epoxidation of propylene using a range of Ag-based catalysts, such as Ag-La2O3, 50 %Ag-MoO3, 20 %Ag-MoO3/ZrO2, 20 %Ag-Y2O3-K2O/α-Al2O3, 60 %Ag-CuCl, and 45 %Ag/CaCO3 [2–7]. However, the PO selectivity rarely exceeds 60 %, and the Ag loading is typically greater than 20 wt%. Size-selected Ag3 clusters supported on Al2O3 can catalyze the epoxidation of propylene with molecular oxygen, producing only minimal amounts of carbon dioxide and exhibiting high activity at low temperatures [8]. However, the catalyst preparation method is overly complex to be widely applicable. Ag-based catalysts demonstrate high activity for propylene epoxidation; however, their selectivity for propylene oxide (PO) remains relatively low. Research groups led by Lopez and Lambert have investigated the mechanism of propylene epoxidation on Ag(111) and Cu(111) surfaces using density functional theory (DFT), revealing that Cu exhibits greater selectivity than Ag in alkene epoxidation [9–11]. The propylene conversion of 0.19 % and the PO selectivity of 43 % were attained over a NaCl-modified VCe1-xCux oxide catalyst [12]. Lambert reported the discovery of a metallic Cu catalyst capable of achieving a propylene conversion of 0.25 % and a propylene PO selectivity of 53 % [13]. When modified with K, CuOx/SBA-15 and Cu/SiO2 catalysts demonstrated improved catalytic performance in the epoxidation of propylene using molecular oxygen, with a PO formation rate reaching 2.5 mmol/g·h [14,15]. While Cu-based catalysts exhibit high PO selectivity, the strong Cu–O bond significantly limits propylene conversion, even at even at high reaction temperatures [16]. Bimetallic catalysts, which often exhibit electronic and chemical properties distinct from those of their individual constituent metals, present an opportunity to develop novel catalysts with improved selectivity, activity, and stability [17]. In our previous work, we synthesized Ag-Cu bimetallic catalysts using a surfactant-protected colloidal method, achieving enhanced catalytic performance compared to other Ag-based bimetallic catalysts [18]. Bimetallic catalysts can indeed be prepared through surfactant-protected colloidal methods, where interactions between polymer functional groups and surface metal atoms can affect catalyst activity and selectivity [19–21]. The modification of Cu species by chlorine species was further demonstrated to enhance the PO selectivity. However, this method diminished the interaction between Ag and Cu species, resulting in a reduction in conversion and stability [16]. In this study, we investigated AgCl-modified Ag-Cu/BaCO3 bimetallic catalysts, prepared via in situ reduction co-deposition without the use of surfactants, for the epoxidation of propylene by molecular oxygen. This study focuses on elucidating the reaction mechanism and the promotional effects of Cu and Cl addition. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalyst 2.9wt.%Ag-0.086wt.%Cu/BaCO3 catalyst (molar ratio Cu/Ag of 1/20), denoted as Ag20Cu/ BaCO3, was prepared as follows: BaCO3 powder was added into NaBH4 aqueous solution under stirring, and the formed slurry was continually stirred for 0.5 h at room temperature. Subsequently, aqueous solutions of AgNO3 and Cu (NO3) 2 were slowly added to the slurry, allowing Ag+ and Cu2+ ions to be reduced to metallic Ag and Cu by NaBH4, resulting in the deposition of Ag-Cu bimetallic nanoparticles on the BaCO3 support. After being stirred for 1 h, the solid obtained by centrifugation was washed with deionized water until the pH reached 7, and then dried under vacuum at room temperature. Finally, the catalyst was calcined at 450 °C in a pure N2 flow for 4 h. The 2.9wt.%Ag/BaCO3 (Ag20/BaCO3) catalyst was prepared using the same procedure. The 2400 ppm (wt.%) AgCl-2.9wt.%Ag-0.086wt.%Cu/BaCO3 catalyst (molar ratio Cu/Ag of 1/20), denoted as Cl-Ag20Cu/BaCO3, was prepared as follows: Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalyst was added in the AgNO3 aqueous solution under stirring. Subsequently, KCl aqueous solution was slowly added to the mixture of AgNO3 aqueous solution and Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalyst, leading to the deposition of onto the Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalyst. After being stirring for 1 h, the solid obtained by centrifugation was washed with de-ionized water, and dried under vacuum at room temperature. Finally, the catalyst was calcined at 450 °C in a pure N2 flow for 4 h. 2400 ppm (wt.%) AgCl-modified-2.9wt.%Ag/BaCO3 (Cl-Ag20/BaCO3) was prepared using the same procedure. 2.2 Characterization of catalyst The XRD patterns of samples were performed on a Bruker AXS D8 Focus diffractometer with CuKα radiation (λ = 0.15406 nm), which was operated at 40 kV and 40 mA. The UV–vis spectra of samples were recorded on a Varian Cary 500 spectrophotometer using the diffuse reflectance technique in the range of 200–800 nm, and BaSO4 was used as the reference. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra were obtained at 25 °C on a Thermo ESCALAB 250 spectrometer with Al Kα (1486.6 eV) radiation as the excitation source. All binding energies (BE) were determined with respect to the C1s line (284.8 eV) originating from adventitious carbon. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of catalysts were obtained on a FEI TECNAI 20S-TWIN operated at electron accelerating voltage of 200 kV. High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images of catalysts were obtained on a JEOL JEM-2010F at electron accelerating voltage of 200 kV. Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) pattern of the sample was performed on an energy dispersive spectrometer detector (IET200) attached to HRTEM (JEOL JEM-2010F), and the catalyst was deposited on Mo grid. The bulk composition of catalyst was determined by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES) on a Thermo Elemental IRIS 1000 instrument. H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were carried out in the conventional flow system equipment with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 300 mg sample was loaded in the quartz tube reactor. The reduction gas was consisted of 5 % H2/N2 (40 mL/min). TPR was run from 30 °C to 450 °C at the rate of 5 °C/min. Temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO) experiments were conducted in the same device as H2-TPR. The 0.1 % O2/N2 mixed gas of 40 mL/min was used and the heating rate was 10 °C/min from room temperature to 450 °C. The outlet gas was monitored by an online quadrupole mass spectrometer (HIDEN HPR20). Temperature-programmed surface reaction (TPSR) was performed in a quartz micro-reactor. Prior to experiments, the catalyst was pretreated under He flow at 450 °C for 2 h to remove adsorbed H2O and other gases, and then the catalyst was cooled to desired adsorption temperature under the He flow and exposed to O2 or C3H6 for 0.5 h. After being cooled down in flowing gases to 30 °C, the catalyst was purged with He for 0.5 h to remove physically adsorbed O2 or C3H6. TPSR was run under 20 % C3H6/He or 20 % O2/He from 30 to 200 °C at 3 °C/min. The outlet gas was monitored by an online quadrupole mass spectrometer (HIDEN HPR20). H2-O2 titration experiments were conducted on Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920, a fully automated chemisorbentimeter. During the experiment, 50 mg of catalyst was weighed into a U-tube and pretreated at 40 mL/min under a mixed atmosphere of 5 vol% H2/N2, heated to 300 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min and maintained for 60 min, then cooled to 200 °C in an atmosphere of He. O2 adsorption was conducted in a series of pulses within a mixed atmosphere comprising 3 vol% O2/He. Subsequently, the atmosphere should be switched and purged for a period of ten minutes. Finally, the H2-O2 titration was conducted in multiple pulses at a flow rate of 40 mL/min under a 5 vol% H2/N2 mixture. The volume of the measuring tube is 0.5173 mL. In gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS) experiments, a thermal desorber (Turbo Matrix 650), a gas chromatograph (Clarus 680) and a mass spectrometer (Clarus SQ 8 T) were employed. The reaction product gas was collected via the activated carbon adsorbent tube and subsequently enriched by the thermal desorber. It was then introduced into the gas chromatography (GC) and mass spectrometry (MS) instruments for separation and detection, respectively. 2.3 Epoxidation of propylene The epoxidation of propylene was carried out in a fixed-bed reactor (Ф6 × 400 mm) with 0.6 g catalyst at atmosphere pressure. The feed gas was consisted of 20 % propylene and 80 % O2, and GHSV was 2000 h−1. Reaction products were analyzed using two on-line gas chromatographs equipped with two packed columns (G.D.X-401 and Porapak Q) with FID and TCD detectors. The deactivated catalysts were regenerated by calcination at 450 °C for 4 h in 0.1 % O2/N2. In kinetic study experiments, the temperature was rapidly increased to the desired temperature (200 °C) from room temperature (Approximately one hour), which was the same experimental procedure used to test stability and deactivation. When the reaction temperature reached 200 °C, the reaction outlet gas was immediately sampled for 1 min and then detected with FID and TCD detectors. The conversion of propylene was calculated using equation (1), where nC3H6 i and nC3H6 o are moles of propylene at the inlet and outlet of the reactor. (1) C o n v e r s i o n % = n C 3 H 6 i - n C 3 H 6 o n C 3 H 6 i × 100 % Reaction product selectivity was calculated according to equation (2), where nPO is moles of product PO. (2) S e l e c t i v i t y % = nPO n C 3 H 6 i - n C 3 H 6 o × 100 % PO formation rate was calculated according to equation (3), where mcat is mass of the catalyst and wAg is the mass percentage of Ag [22]. (3) R PO = n C 3 H 6 i × C o n v e r s i o n % × S e l e c t i v i t y % t × m cat × w Ag 2.4 DFT calculation details All calculations were conducted using Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional [23] within the generalized gradient approximation, implemented through the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [24,25]. The project-augmented wave (PAW) method was used to describe the core-valence electron interaction [26,27]. Spin-polarized calculations were performed, with valence electronic states expanded in a plane wave basis set with a cutoff energy of 450 eV. Atomic positions were relaxed until the sum of the absolute forces was below 0.05 eV/Å, which was demonstrated to be accurate enough by the tighter convergence criteria (0.01) (Table S1). To model Ag (111) and Ag (110) surface, four-layer p (4 × 4) (64 atoms) and p (2 × 3) (48 atoms) slab were used, respectively. To simulate variations in surface Cu distribution on the Ag (111) surface in the Ag95-Cu5 catalyst, a range of adjacent Cu-substituted Ag (111) surfaces (1–4 Cu atoms) was applied, based on experimental observations (Fig. S1). The effects of chorine promoting were investigated at the active site of the reaction structures according to the experimental characterization results (Table S2 and Fig. S2). All calculations employed a 12 Å vacuum layer and a 2 × 2 × 1 k-point mesh with relaxation allowed for the top two slab layers. The transition states (TSs) were located with a constrained method and were verified when (i) all forces on the atoms vanish and (ii) the total energy is a maximum along the reaction coordinate but a minimum with respect to the rest of the degrees of freedom (Figs. S3 and S4) [28–30]. The adsorption energies were defined as follows: (4) E ad = E total - E slab + E gas where Etotal is the total energy of the adsorption system, Eslab is the energy of the clean slab and Egas is the energy of the adsorbed molecule in the gas phase. 2.5 Measurement for OMMP selectivity With respect to the primary chemistry of propylene epoxidation, the atomic oxygen mechanism can be described as follows: (5) C 3 H 6 ∗ + O* ↔ C 3 H 5 ∗ + OH* (6) C 3 H 6 ∗ + O* ↔ OMMP* + ∗ where * represents the free site on the metal surface. The OMMPs are generally accepted as the key intermediates for production of propylene oxide, while the π-allyl can readily combust and lead to poor selectivity towards PO. Thus, we focused our studies on these two elementary reaction steps (similar to molecular oxygen mechanism) and try to simplify the measurement of OMMP selectivity. Within micro-kinetic framework and transition state theory, the reaction rate of step (1) and step (2) can be written as: (7) r 1 = k B T h exp - Δ G a 1 k B T θ C 3 H 6 θ O 1 - Z 1 (8) r 2 = k B T h exp - Δ G a 2 k B T θ C 3 H 6 θ O 1 - Z 2 where θ, θ C3H6 θ C 3 H 6 and θO θ O are the coverage of surface free site, surface adsorbed propylene and atomic oxygen, respectively. T is the reaction temperature and kB and h are constants. Z1 and Z2 are the reaction reversibility of step (1) and (2), expressed as: (9) Z 1 = θ C 3 H 5 θ OH θ C 3 H 6 θ O K e q 1 (10) Z 2 = θ OMMP θ θ C 3 H 6 θ O K e q 2 where θ C3H5 θ C 3 H 6 θ C 3 H 5 , θ OH θ C 3 H 6 θ OH , θ O M M P θ OMMP θ C 3 H 6 are the coverage of surface π-allyl, OH and OMMP, respectively. Keq1 and Keq2 are the reaction equilibrium constant of step (1) and (2), determined by the Gibbs free energy changes and can be expressed as: (11) K e q 1 = exp - Δ G 1 k B T (12) K e q 2 = exp - Δ G 2 k B T The relative reaction rate of step (1) and (2) can be written as: (13) r 1 r 2 = exp - Δ G a k B T 1 - Z 1 1 - Z 2 where ΔGa is the free energy barrier difference between step (1) and step (2). Notably, the ΔG and the ΔG a of each elementary reaction step were corrected with the entropy effects and zero-point energy (ZPE) included, and the entropy of the adsorbed state can be ignored due to very small contributions. In studied cases, ΔG 2 is lower than ΔG 1, which indicate Z1 is properly larger than Z2 (which means 1 - Z 1 1 - Z 2 ≥ 1 or 1 - Z 1 1 - Z 2 ≤ 0 ) without consideration of the coverage effects. For simplify, Eq. (13) can be written as: (14) r 1 r 2 ≈ exp - Δ G a k B T From the Eq. (14), we can see that when ΔGa > 0, the reaction rate of step (1) is lower than step (2), which indicates a better selectivity towards OMMP intermediates. For instance, under the condition of T = 500 K and ΔGa = 0.1 eV, the value of r 1 r 2 is calculated to be 0.01. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance of the catalysts In propylene epoxidation reactions, the selectivity of propylene oxide (PO) is an important performance indicator. Fig. S5 shows the selectivity of PO for propylene epoxidation over Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalyst at different reaction temperatures. At 160 °C, PO began to be produced with a selectivity of 3.6 %. As the temperature increased, PO selectivity gradually rose, reaching 6.7 % at 200 °C. Beyond this temperature, the selectivity of PO gradually declined with further increase in reaction temperature. Furthermore, Fig. S6 indicated that the conversion exhibited a notable decline while the selectivity remained largely unchanged, as the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) increased at 200 °C. Therefore, 200 °C was taken as the reaction temperature in this work. Fig. 1 A illustrates the effect of AgCl promoter on the catalytic performance of Cl-Ag20/BaCO3 catalyst. The addition of AgCl to Ag20/BaCO3 sharply reduced both CO2 and PO formation rates, with a more pronounced reduction in the rate of CO2 formation. Consequently, the addition of AgCl enhances PO selectivity. For instance, a PO selectivity of 31.9 % and a propylene conversion of 0.8 % were achieved over the Cl-Ag20/BaCO3 catalyst at 200 °C. Fig. 1B shows a different trend for the effect of AgCl on the Cl-Ag20/BaCO3 catalyst. With AgCl addition, the rate of CO2 formation declined sharply, while the rate of PO formation initially increases, reaching a maximum of 17.517 mmol/h∙gAg at 2400 ppm AgCl, before subsequently decreasing. Therefore, the presence of AgCl in Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalyst can enhance both the PO selectivity and the rate of PO formation, which is a highly favorable result. Using 2400 ppm AgCl-modified Cl-Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalyst, a PO selectivity of 84.4 % and a propylene conversion of 5.0 % were achieved at 200 °C. Fig. 2 illustrates the effect of reaction temperature on the epoxidation of propylene over the Cl-Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalyst, with product analysis performed using an online quadrupole mass spectrometer (HIDEN HPR20). To eliminate the potential for interference from the C3H6O isomer, GC–MS was utilized, and only PO was identified in both the GC and MS in Fig. S7. The primary products observed during the reaction were PO and CO2, with acrolein selectivity being less than 1 %. Notably, the Cl-Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalyst exhibits high activity at lower reaction temperature, achieving 100 % selectivity for PO (M/z = 58) at 80 °C. The selectivity of PO is observed to decline gradually with an increase in the reaction temperature. Over Cl-Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalyst, the PO selectivity reached 84.4 % at 200 °C, accompanied by a propylene conversion of 5.0 %. This represents one of the most effective catalysts reported to date for the epoxidation of propylene by molecular oxygen. Without AgCl on the surface of the Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalyst, the rate of CO2 formation is considerably faster than the rate of PO formation, and only PO selectivity of 6.7 % and propylene conversion of 19.7 % were achieved over the Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalyst at 200 °C. Fig. S6 shows the effect of the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) on the epoxidation of propylene over Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalyst at 200 °C. Upon increasing the GHSV to 12000 h−1, the conversion declined to 4.6 %, while the selectivity reached only 5.2 %. This is further demonstrated that it is markedly inferior to the selectivity observed with the AgCl-modified catalyst. The promoting effect of AgCl on the active sites and the catalytic performance of Cl-Ag20Cu/BaCO3 is of great importance. 3.2 Kinetic studies The kinetic study was conducted in a fixed-bed reactor for the propylene epoxidation. The application of a high gas flow rate and a catalyst with a small particle size served to eliminate both external and internal mass transfers. The propylene conversion was controlled at a level below 10 %. The external mass transfer limitation was evaluated in accordance with the Mears’ criterion, [31] while the internal mass transfer limitation was evaluated in line with the Weisz-Prater criterion [32]. The detailed calculations are presented in the Supporting Information. The kinetic results, as illustrated in Figs. S8–12, demonstrate that the apparent activation energy of PO formation over the Cl-Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalyst is 35.1 kJ/mol, which is significantly lower than that observed over the Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalyst (76.8 kJ/mol). It has been previously reported that the apparent activation energy of PO formation over a K-modified CuOx/SBA-15 catalyst was 72 kJ/mol [33]. Consequently, the Cl-Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalyst is capable of exhibiting high activity at lower temperatures for the epoxidation of propylene. The difference in apparent activation energy between CO2 formation and PO formation over the Cl-Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalyst is 22.8 kJ/mol, whereas that over the Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalyst is only 1.3 kJ/mol. It can thus be concluded that the addition of AgCl to the Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalyst results in an enhancement of both the rate of PO formation and PO selectivity. Table S3 illustrates that the discrepancy in kinetic parameters between the two catalysts is primarily attributable to the observation that the presence of AgCl has the effect of reducing propylene epoxidation, which is dependent on oxygen. This is evidenced by the decline in the oxygen order from 0.79 to 0.48 (∼0.5), while the order of C3H6 exhibits an increase from −0.34 to 0.05 (∼0). This suggests that the mechanism of propylene epoxidation may be significantly modified by the addition of AgCl to the Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalyst. The stability of the Cl-Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalyst was investigated. Fig. 3 illustrates that the catalytic activity of the Cl-Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalyst undergoes fluctuations over time. For instance, the propylene conversion declined from 5.0 % to 1.8 % after reaction for 6 h, while the selectivity for PO remained largely unchanged. As illustrated in Fig. 1, the content of chlorine species played a pivotal role in the PO selectivity. The constant PO selectivity indicated that the chlorine species did not remove from the surface during the reaction, which was consistent with the results in Table S2. The aforementioned results demonstrate that the nature of the active sites should be altered, although the number of such sites has been reduced. Based on the rate of catalyst deactivation (Approximately 0.01 % / min) in Fig. 3, the conversion of the catalyst decreased by 0.01 % during the time at which the reaction outlet gas was collected (1 min) in the kinetic experiments, which can neglect the effect of catalyst deactivation. 3.3 Characterization of catalysts In order to gain insight into the deactivation of the Cl-Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalyst, both fresh and deactivated catalysts were subjected to characterisation by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO). As illustrated in Fig. S13, the particle size distribution of the Ag20Cu/BaCO3 and Cl-Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalysts remained largely unchanged before and after the reaction, indicating that active site density remained constant. Furthermore, it can be observed that the incorporation of AgCl resulted in an increase in particle size, resulting in a decrease in the Ag sites that may be susceptible to oxidation. The TPO curves are presented in Fig. S14. The deactivated Cl-Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalyst released a considerable quantity of CO2 and H2O during TPO, whereas the fresh catalyst only produces trace amounts of CO2 (and no water). The TG-MS profiles of the fresh and used catalysts are presented in Fig. S15. A calculation was performed to determine the weight loss due to coke based on the observed difference in weight loss before and after the reaction. This phenomenon indicates that the coking was the cause of the catalyst deactivation, as coking was oxidized to CO2 and H2O on the deactivated catalyst and carbonaceous species deposited can be removed by oxidation at 450 °C. Consequently, the deactivated catalyst can be restored through calcination at 450 °C for 4 h in an atmosphere of 0.1 % O2/N2 (Fig. 3B). The structure of the Cl-AgxCu/BaCO3 catalysts was determined by XRD and HRTEM. The XRD patterns of the Cl-AgxCu/BaCO3 catalysts with different Ag/Cu molar ratios are presented in Fig. S16. In these XRD patterns, the characteristic diffraction peaks of Ag (111) and Ag (220) are observed at 2θ = 38.2°, 64.5° respectively, due to the loading of Ag at a concentration of 2.9 wt%. The diffraction peaks of Ag (111) and the corresponding lattice constant values remain largely unaltered with increasing Cu content, which suggests that the formation of Ag-Cu alloy is unlikely. The diffraction peaks of Cu and AgCl are not observable due to the insufficient loading. Fig. 4 shows the HAADF-STEM and EDS-Mapping of Ag20Cu/BaCO3 and Cl-Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalysts. The average size of Ag-Cu nanoparticles is 30–40 nm (Fig. S14). However, the distribution of Ag species and Cu species was not consistent, indicating that these two components did not form the Ag-Cu alloy. Instead, the majority of Ag and Cu particles are present in forms that are in close proximity to one another on the surface of BaCO3. As illustrated in Fig. S17, the lattice fringes of the nanoparticle attached to the BaCO3 support are distinctly discernible. The observed lattice spacing of 0.232 nm corresponds to the Ag (111) crystal plane, indicating that the lattice spacing of the Ag (111) plane remains largely unaltered following the introduction of Cu into the Ag20/BaCO3 catalyst. In a word, it can be stated that the nanoparticles in question are of the Ag-Cu bimetallic variety, rather than an Ag-Cu alloy, in which the majority of Cu species are dispersed on the surface of Ag or within the bulk of Ag nanoparticles. XPS was used to investigate the valence states of Cl-Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalyst, and the results are shown in Fig. S18. On the fresh Cl-Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalyst, the binding energy of Ag3d5/2 was 367.8 eV, which was attributed to Ag0. This indicated that Ag is predominately metallic on the fresh catalyst. After the propylene epoxidation, the shape of the peaks remained largely unchanged, with a mere 0.2 eV shift in peak positions. This observation suggests that Ag0 maintained its dominance as the primary valence state throughout the reaction. However, a shift in the peak position towards lower binding energies confirmed the partial oxidation of Ag species on the surface during the reaction. The slightly oxidized Ag surface is more likely to form Agx-O2 structure, which facilitates the epoxidation reaction [34–36]. The binding energies of Cu2p3/2 and Cu2p1/2 of used Cl-Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalyst are 931.6 and 951.7 eV respectively, which is ascribed to Cu1+ or Cu0 because Cu2p XPS spectrum of Cu1+ is almost the same as that of Cu0 [37]. Furthermore, the intensity of Cu2p peak decreased on the used-Cl-Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalyst. Given that Ag species and Cu species both exhibited a decline in atomic occupancy (Table S2) and when considered alongside the TG-MS (Fig. S15), it can be concluded that this phenomenon is related to the deactivation of the catalyst via coking. The deactivated catalysts were regenerated by calcination, which was due to the remove of the accumulated carbon species to exposes the covered active sites. As illustrated in Fig. S19 and Table S2, the content and valence of Cl exhibited minimal variation before and after the reaction, indicating that chlorine species was stable on the surface. In the context of propylene epoxidation, the active adsorption of oxygen on Cl-AgxCu/BaCO3 represents a crucial process. Consequently, in order to ascertain the reactivity of the oxygen adsorbed on the catalyst surface, Cl-AgxCu/BaCO3 catalysts were subjected to a pre-treatment at 200 °C for 0.5 h in an oxygen atmosphere prior to the TPR experiment. Fig. 5 A illustrates the H2-TPR profiles of the Ag/BaCO3, Cl-Ag/BaCO3 and Cu/BaCO3 catalysts. The TPR profile of the Ag/BaCO3 catalyst exhibits a reduction peak associated with surface-adsorbed oxygen species at 40 °C. Following the addition of Cl to the Ag/BaCO3 catalyst, the reduction peak shifts to approximately 67 °C. This may be attributed to the effect of Cl on the Ag surface, which may result in a reduction in the reactivity of oxygen species adsorbed on the Ag surface. In the case of the Cu/BaCO3 catalyst, the reduction peak, located at approximately 188 °C, is ascribed to the reduction of oxygen species adsorbed on the Cu surface. Fig. 5B illustrates the impact of Cu loading on the reduction property of the Cl-Ag20Cux/BaCO3 catalyst. The H2-TPR profiles of Cl-Ag20Cux/BaCO3 catalysts exhibit three distinct reduction peaks, designated as α, β, and γ. The α peak observed at approximately 105 °C, is attributed to the reduction of oxygen adsorbed on the Ag surface. The β peak, observed at approximately 152 °C (including the γ peak at 195 °C) is believed to be related to Cu loading, as the peak area (i.e., H2 consumption) increases with increasing Cu loading (an increase in the molar ratio of Cu/Ag). As illustrated in Fig. S20, the UV–vis absorption spectrum of the monometallic Ag catalyst exhibits an absorption peak at a wavelength of 415 nm, which can be attributed to the resonance absorption peak of Ag in the zero-valence state. With the introduction of Cu, the absorption peak gradually shifts towards higher wavelengths, which indicated that the addition of Cu species resulted in the alteration in the state of Ag species instead of physical mixture. In conjunction with the HRTEM findings, it can be posited that the active sites of Cl-Ag20Cux/BaCO3 are derived from the bimetallic nanoparticles, rather than a mere physical mixture of Ag and Cu nanoparticles. The reactivity of oxygen species adsorbed on an Ag-Cu bimetallic surface is significantly higher than that observed on a Cu surface. It can therefore be concluded that the β reduction peak at 152 °C is ascribed to the reduction of oxygen species adsorbed on the Ag-Cu bimetallic surface. observed at approximately 195 °C, is attributed to the reduction of oxygen species adsorbed on the Cu surface. The results demonstrate that the TPR curve (Fig. 5C) of Cl-Ag20Cu/BaCO3 pretreated with oxygen at 200 °C for 0.5 h exhibits a profile that is comparable to that of the fresh catalyst. The H2-TPR profile of Cl-Ag20Cu/BaCO3, which has been pretreated with oxygen and then with C3H6 at 200 °C for 1 h, exhibits two reduction peaks, which are identified as β and γ peaks (Fig. 5C). The α peak, which resulted from oxygen species adsorbed on the Ag surface, disappeared concomitantly with a reduction in the β peak area. This suggests that the oxygen species adsorbed on the Ag surface and a portion of the oxygen species on the Ag-Cu bimetallic surface have undergone a reaction with propylene. The reduction peak at 196 °C of oxygen species adsorbed on the Cu surface broadened. This was probably due to the decomposition of the carbonate species on Cu surface. The aforementioned TPR results indicate that the oxygen species adsorbed on the Ag or Ag-Cu bimetallic surface exhibit higher activity for propylene oxidation or epoxidation, whereas the oxygen species adsorbed on the Cu surface exhibit lower activity for propylene oxidation or epoxidation at 200 °C. In light of the findings pertaining to catalytic activity as illustrated in Figs. 1 and 2, it can be posited that the oxygen species adsorbed on Ag or AgCl sites demonstrate a diminished propensity for propylene epoxidation. Conversely, the oxygen species adsorbed on Ag-Cu (Cl-Ag-Cu) bimetallic sites exhibit a marked capacity for epoxidation of propylene to PO. The presence of AgCl in the Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalyst has been demonstrated to markedly enhance the selectivity and rate of PO formation, while simultaneously inhibiting the formation of CO2. Fig. 5D illustrates the impact of AgCl loading on the reduction property of the Cl-Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalyst. The findings demonstrate that with an increase in AgCl loading, the β and γ peaks exhibit a gradual shift towards higher temperatures, while the α peak initially shifts to a higher temperature (∼106 °C) and subsequently shifts to a lower temperature (∼100 °C). The Cl element is more electronegative than the Ag element and can therefore withdraw electrons from the surface Ag atoms, resulting in an increase in the Ag work function [38]. It can be reasonably deduced that adsorbed Cl atoms may exert an influence on the adsorption property of Ag for oxygen, the bond strength of Ag-O and the reactivity of oxygen species adsorbed on the catalyst surface. Notably, for Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalyst without AgCl, the reduction temperature of α peak also shifted to the high temperatures, which indicated that the interaction between Ag and Cu species occurred. Furthermore, Fig. S21 illustrates that 31 % of the Ag species were oxidised to Ag2O over the Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalysts. Concurrently, the volume of H2 required for reduction and the volume of O2 consumed for pre-oxidation are more than 2:1. This indicates that the Ag species on Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalyst are more easily oxidized while simultaneously promoting the complete oxidation of propylene, thereby reducing the selectivity of PO to a significant extent. For the Cl-Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalyst, the theoretical oxidation rate of Ag species was calculated to be 23 % resulting from an increase in particle size. However, the actual hydrogen used for the Cl-Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalyst was considerably less than the theoretical hydrogen consumption resulting from the increase in particle size. This indicates that the reduction in hydrogen consumption was not attributable to the increase in particle size, but rather to the addition of AgCl, which inhibited the dissociation of oxygen species. Furthermore, the ratio of the volume of H2 required for reduction and the volume of O2 consumed for pre-oxidation on Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalyst was more than that on Cl-Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalyst. This indicated that oxygen species on Cl- Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalyst are predominantly molecular oxygen species, while those on Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalyst are predominantly atomic oxygen species, which is attributed to an increase rate of molecular oxygen dissociation into active oxygen atoms, subsequently reacting with H2.This indicates that the oxygen adsorbed on the Cl-Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalyst did not dissociate rapidly, thereby enhancing the selectivity of propylene oxide. 3.4 First-principles density functional theory studies Aiming at illustrating the origin of enhanced selectivity for PO formation on Ag-Cu bimetallic catalyst with chorine promoting, first-principles density functional theory calculations were carried out to explore the inherent reaction mechanism and promotion effect of Cu and Cl addition. Epoxidation of propylene by molecular oxygen over silver- and copper-based catalysts are generally assumed to follow the atomic oxygen mechanism [11,39,40]. As shown in Scheme 1 A, upon adsorption and dissociation of O2 on the metal surface, the formed O* atom as active species can react with the adsorbed propylene to form oxametallacycle (OMMP) intermediate, or alternatively undergo the allylic hydrogen stripping reaction (AHS) and eventually give rise to the complete oxidation of propylene into CO2. These two parallel reactions constitute the first reaction stage, namely, the primary chemistry proposed by R. M. Lambert and coworkers [11]. Therefore, herein we will mainly discuss the effect of Cu and Cl promoter on the control of primary chemistry on Ag catalyst. Even though the atomic oxygen mechanism has been widely accepted, one can see that it hardly explains the high selectivity of Cl modified Ag-Cu bimetallic catalyst toward OMMP and consequent PO formation based on the above discussion. Moreover, with respect to the active form of oxygen on the catalyst surface, long debates [41–45] remain to be solved and the molecular oxygen mechanism cannot be ruled out for a variety of reaction conditions. The adsorption of O2 (see Fig. S22a) is slightly exothermic (ca. −0.1 eV) on pure Ag (111) surface at the oxygen coverage of 0.125, which is rather weak, especially corresponding to an adsorption free energy of 0.80 eV with the entropy effect of O2 included at 500 K. The dissociated oxygen adatoms are in favor of the threefold fcc site with an adsorption energy of −0.55 eV at the coverage of 0.063. O2 dissociation occurs through transition state with O-O distance of 1.904 Å (Fig. S22) and the activation barrier is calculated to be 0.71 eV, which is in good agreement with previously investigation at the PW91 level (0.64 eV) for the same oxygen coverage [3]. The adsorption of O2 become much weaker (0.03 eV endothermic) when a chorine adatom co-adsorbed near oxygen on Ag (111) surface (see Fig. S22a), and dissociation also become more difficult with a barrier of 0.79 eV. When one Cu is introduced into Ag (111) surface, the strength of molecular and atomic oxygen adsorption is largely enhanced (−0.64 and −1.20 eV, respectively), and the dissociation barrier is decreased (0.27 eV). With the amount of substituted Cu atoms increases (see Fig. S22), the adsorption of oxygen become more exothermic and the activation energies for O2 dissociation decreases to a range between 0.13 and 0.08 eV, as shown in Table S4. Therefore, Cu promoter can increase the adsorption and dissociation. However, the presence of co-adsorbed Cl atoms is likely to competitively occupy the active site for oxygen adsorption owing to the larger adsorption energy of Cl compared to O adatom (see entries 6 and 7 in Table S4), and as a result, the binding and dissociation of oxygen species is expected to be inhibited. Overall, the results indicate that the subtle control of surface concentration of chorine and copper can probably lead to a molecular oxygen-rich surface and the mechanism of PO formation may switch to another pathway. The molecular oxygen mechanism is shown in Scheme 1B. Different from the atomic oxygen mechanism, the adsorbed O2 can react with propylene directly and form a new kind of oxametallacycle (OMMPʹ) configuration, then the O-O bond of OMMPʹ can cleave and produce OMMP (see Scheme 1B) and an oxygen adatom. Further cyclization of OMMP can produce PO, while the oxygen adatom can react with propylene following the atomic oxygen mechanism. Selected optimized transition state (TS) structures for OMMPʹ formation and AHS pathway on a series of Ag-Cu catalyst surface are given in Fig. 6 . Taking Ag (111) as an example, the formed OMMPʹ structure is illustrated in Fig. 6a, which can further decompose into OMMP via transition state of O-O bond cleavage (Fig. 6b). Based on DFT calculation, it is found that the AHS process has a higher barrier (0.42 eV) compared with that of atomic oxygen mechanism (0.13 eV) on Ag (111) surface, while the reaction barriers for OMMPʹ formation is as low as 0.15 eV. Interestingly, the consequent O-O bond cleavage of OMMPʹ can also readily occur with a low barrier of 0.21 eV. Furthermore, the O-O bond cleavage barriers of the OMMPʹ intermediate on kinds of Ag-Cu surfaces are calculated to be between 0.03 and 0.05 eV (see Table S5), indicating the facile formation of OMMP species from OMMPʹ. Particularly, on these surfaces, the barrier of O-O cleavage is lower than that of OMMPʹ formation (see Table S5). Therefore, similar to the atomic oxygen mechanism, here the relative difference (ΔEa ) between the barriers of AHS’ and OMMPʹ formation reactions can also be approximately considered to act as the measurement of the selectivity towards OMMP. A systematic investigation of ΔEa was carried out on a series of Ag-Cu surfaces. On Ag (111) surface, the barrier difference (ΔEa ) of 0.27 eV indicates that the selectivity towards OMMP is better than AHS reaction. When one Cu atom was introduced into Ag (111) surface, the barriers for AHS’ and OMMPʹ formation on the resulted local configuration “2Ag1Cu” (see Fig. S23b) reaction are calculated to be 0.48 and 0.27 eV (see Table S5), respectively, which are slightly higher than those on pure Ag (111) surface. The corresponding ΔEa value (0.21 eV) is smaller than that on pure Ag, suggesting that the selectivity of the oxametallacycle intermediate decreases and that of allyl increases. On local configuration “1Ag2Cu” (see Fig. S23c), the barriers for these two parallel reactions, giving 0.36 and 0.05 eV, respectively, are both lower than those on Ag (111) surface, but the value of ΔEa (0.31 eV) is close to that on Ag (111). The consequent O-O bond cleavage can also readily occur, giving a barrier as low as 0.05 eV. Thus, one can see that the introduction of double-Cu can change much the selectivity of OMMPʹ and AHS’ pathway, while it facilitates the cleavage of O-O bond of OMMPʹ, which benefits the formation of OMMP and PO as a result. From Table S5, one can see that on local configuration “1Ag2Cu”, the relative barrier difference (ΔEa ) reaches the highest values (0.31 eV) following the molecular oxygen mechanism, indicating that the best selectivity towards PO. The reaction profile of primary chemistry following the molecular oxygen mechanism on this surface is illustrated in Fig. 6e, in which the atomic oxygen mechanism was also plotted as a comparison. In molecular oxygen mechanism, the adsorbed O2 reacts with propylene by overcoming a barrier of 0.36 eV to form allyl and OOH species and being endothermic by 0.15 eV; the corresponding transition state structure is shown in Fig. 6c, giving a C–H bond length of 1.349 Å. OMMPʹ is formed via transition state structure with C-O bond length of 1.890 Å and giving an energy gain of 0.05 eV. The thermodynamic and kinetics advantages directly lead to the excellent selectivity towards OMMP intermediate. While in atomic oxygen mechanism, even though the thermodynamic is favored in OMMP formation, the higher barrier would hinder this pathway and the corresponding selectivity towards OMMP is bad. Further, by comparing atomic and molecular oxygen mechanism on a series of Ag-Cu surfaces (Tables S5 and S6), one can see that the presence of molecular oxygen mechanism increases the barrier of α-H stripping pathway, but interestingly decreases the barrier of OMMP formation. In this case, the selectivity of PO formation can be expected to increase considerably. Therefore, one solution to make the molecular oxygen mechanism work is to design the catalyst that can efficiently adsorb O2 (and propylene) but do not dissociate it directly. The addition of Cl or AgCl promoter is possibly such a consideration in hindering O2 direct dissociation. 4 Conclusions AgCl-modified Ag-Cu/BaCO3 bimetallic catalysts, prepared by in situ reduction co-deposition methods, can significantly enhance both the rate of PO formation and PO selectivity. Using 2400 ppm AgCl-modified Cl-Ag20Cu/BaCO3 catalyst, PO selectivity of 84.4 % and propylene conversion of 5.0 % can be achieved at 200 °C. Kinetic studies have shown that for Ag-Cu bimetallic catalysts, the addition of AgCl not only inhibits the total oxidation of propylene, but also significantly reduces the activation energy of the propylene epoxidation reaction. Through first-principles density functional theory studies, it can be found that Cl and AgCl can inhibit the dissociation of oxygen molecules, making the molecular oxygen mechanism work instead of the atomic oxygen mechanism, which can facilitate the propylene epoxidation reaction. In conclusion, AgCl modification of Ag-Cu bimetallic catalysts is a good way to improve the reactivity of propylene epoxidation reaction. coredata.dc:description: As molecular oxygen is the cheapest oxidant, the epoxidation of propylene by molecular oxygen is a topic of great interest and also the most challenge topic in the heterogeneous catalysis. However, the epoxidation of propylene by only molecular oxygen has yet to be optimised to a significant extent. Here we show, AgCl-modified Ag20Cu/BaCO3 bimetallic catalysts, prepared by in situ reduction co-deposition methods, were demonstrated to exhibit excellent catalytic activity for the epoxidation of propylene. First-principles density functional theory calculations were carried out to explore the inherent reaction mechanism and promotion effect of Cu and Cl addition. The addition of AgCl to Ag20Cu/BaCO3 bimetallic catalyst inhibited total oxidation of propylene, but enhanced both the rate of PO formation and PO selectivity. The highest PO selectivity of ∼100 % was achieved over 2400 ppm AgCl-Ag20Cu-/BaCO3 bimetallic catalyst at 80 °C.
